Q: pg_upgrade for Postgres12 failing with PG_VERSION A:

Steps that finally worked for the upgrade are :

  1. Stop the old instance.
  2. Install pg12 binary
  3. Initiate an empty instance/cluster to the new target data directory.
  4. Stop both the new instances.
  5. Run the pg_upgrade from the pg12 binary location and perform post steps.
  6. Remove the old instance and data directory.

Q: Kivy RecycleView - dynamically updating element attributes A:

Because the RecycleView reuses the Widgets in its list, you must set the background color every time the text gets set, not just when it gets set to Pass. An easy way to do that is to use a ListProperty for the background color in the MyLabel class:

class MyLabel(Label):
    bg_color = ListProperty([0, 0, 0, 1])

    def on_text(self, _, newtext):
        if newtext == 'Pass':
            self.bg_color = [0, .5, 0, 1]
        else:
            self.bg_color = [1, .85, .85, 1]

with the canvas instructions just created once in the 'kv' file:

<MyLabel>:
    canvas.before:
        Color:
            rgba: self.bg_color
        Rectangle:
            size: self.size
            pos: self.pos

Q: Visual Studio - vdproj is incompatible A:

It's the year 2025 and I confirm that this works also in Visual Studio 2026!

The correct procedure to resolve "Incompatible" issue with VDPROJ Projects coming from Visual Studio 2010 and 2015 in 2017, 2019, 2022 is:

  1. Enter Visual Studio .NET 2017, 2019 or 2022
    • 2017: Click on "Tools" -> Extension and Updates -> Online
    • 2019 or higher: Click on "Extensions" -> Manage Extensions -> Online
  3. Type "Installer Project" on the search box
  4. Click on "Install" in Microsoft Visual Studio Installer Project
  5. Restart Visual Studio .NET and follow the instructions to install the extension
  6. Right click on the projects which have "Incompatible" and click "reload" (tested in VS2022).

With this extension the old project (2010, 2015) is capable to work in (2017, 2019, 2022). VDPROJ are not deprecated, simply they are improved with a new extension, for more information about this please visit the oficial MarketPlace.

Q: Read a jsonl (json lines) file A:

You can convert your JSONL file into a valid JSON array by adding [ at the beginning, replacing each newline (\n) with a comma, and closing with ]. That way jsonlite::fromJSON can parse it directly.

Or you can read JSONL line by line and bind the results:

con <- file("tech.jsonl", "r")
df_list <- list()
while(TRUE) {
  line <- readLines(con, n = 1)
  if(length(line) == 0) break
  df_list <- append(df_list, list(fromJSON(line)))
}
close(con)

df <- bind_rows(df_list)

For very large files, manual conversion can be slow. In that case, you can upload your JSONL to an online tool (I use, JSONLify https://jsonlify.com/ ) to quickly convert it into JSON ARRAY, Excel, or CSV before loading and than format/beautify

Q: How to select all attributes (*) with distinct values in a particular column(s)? A:

You need to select all values from customers table, where city is unique. So, logically, I came with such query:

SELECT *
FROM customers
WHERE city IN (SELECT DISTINCT city FROM customers)
